newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo gold futures firmer, platinum weaker.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo gold futures firmer, platinum weaker.

text.p: Yen-based Tokyo gold futures settled firmer across the board on Wednesday, buoyed by firmer bullion prices, while platinum futures eased on profit-taking, traders said.
Gold futures ranged from four to six yen per gram higher. Most-active benchmark October was five yen higher at 1,358 yen.
Platinum futures ranged from flat to six yen per gram lower. Benchmark October was three yen lower at 1,379 yen.
"Buying in gold futures by private investors emerged at the opening, reflecting the yen's weaker tone, but activity became quiet as the buying ebbed later," one trader said.

Price gains in gold futures were capped by profit-taking amid views the dollar's upside will be limited and expectations that spot gold will be tough to break above its upside resistance at $383.50 in the near term.
In the bullion market, spot gold was quoted at $382.40/70 per ounce at the Tokyo close, against $382.20/70 in New York on Tuesday.
Spot gold lacked clear direction and was sandwiched between moderate buying by Japanese trade houses and profit-taking selling, the traders said.
Platinum futures opened firmer, encouraged by the fact that spot platinum rebounded above $387 per ounce, but platinum futures later succumbed to technical-driven profit-taking.
The gold-platinum spread showed signs of widening as a result of recent rises in platinum futures.
Silver futures ranged from 1.2 yen per 10 grams lower to 1.3 yen firmer. Benchmark October was flat at 178.5 yen.
After sluggish trade, palladium futures ranged from one yen to five yen per gram higher. Benchmark October was up two yen at 424 yen. -- Tokyo Commodity Desk +81-3-3432-7431
